TITLE I--ADDITION OF CAT ISLAND TO GULF ISLANDS NATIONAL SEASHORE

SEC. 101. BOUNDARY ADJUSTMENT TO INCLUDE CAT ISLAND.

(a) In General.--Amends the first section of Public Law 91-660 to include Cat Island in Gulf Islands National Seashore. The establishment of Cat Island in Gulf Islands National Seashore is outlined in the amendment, specifying the composition and boundaries of the area. Upon acquisition by the Secretary, Cat Island will consist of approximately 2,000 acres of land in Mississippi. The Cat Island Map, part of the Gulf Islands National Seashore in Mississippi, is available for public inspection. Amendments to Public Law 91-660 grant the Secretary acquisition authority for submerged land and parcels described in the law. The curr_chunk describes the acquisition of land on Cat Island in Mississippi, including parcels above the mean line of high tide, an easement over the Boddie Family Tract, and land outside the designated area on the Cat Island Map. This acquisition also includes submerged land within a one-mile buffer zone seaward of Cat Island. The Secretary, through the National Park Service, administers land acquired on Cat Island in Mississippi, including submerged land within a one-mile buffer zone. The State of Mississippi is not required to convey any rights in the buffer zone for the establishment of the buffer zone. The boundary of the seashore will be modified to reflect the land acquisition. The seashore boundary will be modified after land acquisition. Fishing regulation authority is limited, and maritime activities outside the designated boundary are not affected. Management agreements authorization is amended. Law 91-660 (16 U.S.C. 459h-4) is amended to allow the Secretary to enter agreements with the State of Mississippi for managing resources and providing law enforcement assistance on Cat Island. Additionally, agreements can be made with the owners of the 'Boddie Family Tract' for development and use of the land. No authority is given to enforce certain regulations. In addition to amending Public Law 91-660 to allow agreements for managing resources and law enforcement on Cat Island, Mississippi, the Secretary is not authorized to enforce certain regulations outside the designated land area. Authorization is also given for the acquisition of land and submerged land on and adjacent to Cat Island. TITLE II--PECOS NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK LAND EXCHANGE

SEC. 201. SHORT TITLE.

    This title may be cited as the ``Pecos National Historical Park 
Land Exchange Act of 2000''.

SEC. 202. DEFINITIONS.

    As used in this title--
            (1) the term ``Secretaries'' means the Secretary of the 
        Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture;
            (2) the term ``landowner'' means Harold and Elisabeth 
        Zuschlag, owners of land within the Pecos National Historical 
        Park; and
            (3) the term ``map'' means a map entitled ``Proposed Land 
        Exchange for Pecos National Historical Park'', numbered 430/
        80,054, and dated November 19, 1999, revised September 18, 
        2000.

SEC. 203. LAND EXCHANGE. Upon conveyance of lands to the Secretary of the Interior, the Secretary of Agriculture will convey approximately 160 acres of Federal lands within Santa Fe National Forest in New Mexico and an easement for water pipelines to two existing well sites in Pecos National Historical Park. The route of the easement through the park will be determined by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of the Interior may add additional terms and conditions to the easement for the well and pipeline in compliance with Federal laws. The landowner will convey approximately 154 acres within Pecos National Historical Park to the Secretary of the Interior, subject to approval of the deed by the Secretary of Agriculture. The exchange of lands and interests under this title must comply with Federal laws, including the National Environmental Policy Act. Appraisals using nationally recognized standards, such as the Uniform Appraisal Standards for Federal Land Acquisition, will determine the equal values of the lands and interests to be exchanged. The Secretaries will ensure the appraisals are conducted accordingly and paid for as per the exchange agreement. The exchange of lands and interests under this title must comply with Federal laws, including the National Environmental Policy Act. Appraisals shall be paid for in accordance with the exchange agreement between the Secretaries and the landowner. The exchange must be completed within 180 days after meeting NEPA requirements and approval of appraisals by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretaries may impose additional terms and conditions to protect interests in the exchange. The Secretary of Agriculture will equalize the values of Federal land conveyed under subsection (a) by payment of cash, with the option to accept a cash equalization payment exceeding 25 percent of the land value. The Secretary of Agriculture will equalize the values of Federal land conveyed by payment of cash, with the option to accept a cash equalization payment exceeding 25 percent of the land value. Any funds received from the exchange will be deposited into a fund for land acquisition in New Mexico. SEC. 204. BOUNDARY ADJUSTMENT AND MAPS. Upon acceptance of title by the Secretary of the Interior, the boundaries of Pecos National Historical Park will be adjusted to include conveyed lands. The Secretary will administer the lands according to National Park System laws. A map will be available for public inspection, and within 180 days of the exchange, an accurate map will be transmitted to the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the United States Senate. The boundaries of Pecos National Historical Park will be adjusted to include conveyed lands, which will be administered according to National Park System laws. An accurate map will be transmitted to the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the United States Senate within 180 days of the exchange. The Senate passed the legislation on October 27, 2000.
